questions.text: Name the phenomenon in which the affected persons may refuse to urinate because they believe they will flood the world? (**)
Which of the following with regard to cannabis use in schizophrenia is incorrect? (**)

options.label: A
options.text: Cannabis use could be a self medication attempt

options.label: B
options.text: Both schizophrenia and cannabis use are high in lower socioeconomic group

options.label: C
options.text: Cannabis intoxication is indistinguishable from schizophrenia

options.label: D
options.text: Cannabis is associated with schizophrenia in a dose-dependent fashion

questions.correct_answer: C. Cannabis intoxication is indistinguishable from schizophrenia

questions.text: Which of the following is a neurological illness that mimics schizophrenic speech disturbance?

Which of the following is not true about type II schizophrenia? (**)
Defect of conation is seen in ? (*)

“Match box” sign is seen in? (PGI MAY 19)

Arnab is a model patient on the ward. He is never in any trouble. Whatever he is told to do he does. He sits quietly for hours, rarely talking, and hardly moving, except to ape the movements of those who pass by him. The most likely diagnosis for Arnab is
A schizophrenia patient on Haloperidol shows improvement in positive symptoms but develops akathisia and dystonia. Which drug can be beneficial the most in this patient? (JIPMER DEC 19)

Match the given case scenarios with the most appropriate diagnosis from given options. "THEME: Psychotic symptoms" A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician accompanied by her husband. He says that for the past 3 months she has refused to eat any food that is not prepackaged. The patient also has placed a lock on the cabinet where she keeps her food and refuses to go to restaurants or eat at social events unless there is unopened, prepackaged food available. Otherwise, she is her normal self. She continues to work and recently received a promotion. The patient believes that someone is coming into her home and poisoning her food. A few months ago, she noticed a tiny hole in an apple at home and was convinced that someone had injected it with poison. She has no past psychiatric history. Except for these beliefs, her mental status examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • (C) Paranoid personality disorder – Incorrect. Paranoid personality disorder is a personality disorder characterized by a pervasive pattern of distrust and suspiciousness of others, where the individual believes others are exploiting, harming, or deceiving them. However, this disorder does not involve specific delusions like the one seen in this patient. The patient's delusional belief (someone is poisoning her food) is more fixed and specific than the general suspiciousness seen in paranoid personality disorder, and it is the hallmark of delusional disorder, not a personality disorder.
  • • (D) Schizophrenia – Incorrect. Schizophrenia typically presents with multiple psychotic symptoms, such as delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and disorganized or catatonic behavior, and these symptoms must last for at least 6 months. This patient’s symptoms are limited to a specific delusion about food poisoning, and there are no other psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations or disorganized behavior. Additionally, her functioning in other areas of life, such as her job and promotion, is preserved, which is not typical in schizophrenia.
  • • (E) Schizophreniform disorder – Incorrect. Schizophreniform disorder is similar to schizophrenia but is diagnosed when psychotic symptoms are present for at least 1 month but less than 6 months. This diagnosis would require the presence of multiple psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech/behavior) and significant functional impairment, which is not the case in this patient. The patient’s symptoms are limited to a delusion without the accompanying symptoms or significant functional impairment.
  • • (F) Schizotypal personality disorder – Incorrect. Schizotypal personality disorder is a personality disorder marked by eccentric behavior, odd beliefs, and social deficits, but delusions are not a defining characteristic. The patient's fixed belief about food poisoning is more indicative of delusional disorder than of schizotypal personality disorder, which typically involves odd beliefs or magical thinking without fixed delusions.

He says that for the past 3 months she has refused to eat any food that is not prepackaged. The patient also has placed a lock on the cabinet where she keeps her food and refuses to go to restaurants or eat at social events unless there is unopened, prepackaged food available. Otherwise, she is her normal self. She continues to work and recently received a promotion. The patient believes that someone is coming into her home and poisoning her food. A few months ago, she noticed a tiny hole in an apple at home and was convinced that someone had injected it with poison. She has no past psychiatric history. Except for these beliefs, her mental status examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 24-year-old man is brought to your emergency department under arrest by the local police. The patient was found naked at a busy intersection jumping up and down on top of a car. Interviewing the patient, you discover that he has not slept in 2 days because he does not feel tired. He reports hearing voices. The patient was previously hospitalized 1 year ago with auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and a normal mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Vasanthi 45 years, was brought to casualty with abnormal movements which included persistent deviation of neck to right side one day before she was prescribed Haloperidol 5 mgs three times daily from the psychiatry OPD. She also had an altercation with her husband recently. Which of the following is the most likely cause for her symptoms?

A patient with acute psychosis, who is on haloperidol 20mg/day for last 2 days, has an episode characterized by tongue protrusion, oculogyric crisis, stiffness and abnormal posture of limbs and trunk without loss of consciousness for last 20 minutes before presenting to casualty. This improved within a few minutes after administration of diphenhy-dramine HCI. The most likely diagnosis is-

A 30 year old manic patient was prescribed haloperidol one week back. For the last two days he has become restless and kept pacing in the room for a day. On examination he was found to have tremors of hand. He is most likely suffering from –

A 19 year old BOY suffering from chronic schizophrenia is put on haloperidol in the dose of 20 mg/day. A week after the initiation of medication the patient shows restlessness, fidgety, irritability and cannot sit still at one place. The most appropriate treatment strategy is -

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in the dose of haloperidol

questions.text: An elderly woman suffering from schizophrenia is on antipsychotic medication. She developed purposeless involuntary facial and limb movements, constant chewing and puffing of cheeks. Which of the following drugs is least likely to be involved in this side effect?

A 30 year old man who was recently started on haloperidol 30mg/day developed hyperpyrexia, muscle rigidity, akinesia, mutism, sweating, tachycardia and increased blood pressure. The investigations showed increased WBC count, increased creatinine phosphokinase. There is no history of any other drug intake or any signs of infection. The most likely diagnosis

A 31 year old male, with mood disorder, on 30 mg of haloperidol and 1000 mg of lithium, is brought to the hospital emergency room with history of acute onset of fever, excessive sweating, confusion, rigidity of limbs and decreased communication for a day. Examination reveals tachycardia and labile blood pressure and investigations reveal increased CPK enzyme levels and leucocytosis. He is likely to havedeveloped

A patient is brought to the casualty in the state of altered sensorium. He was on lithium treatment for affective fits. On examination he has tremors, increased DTR's and incontinence of urine. He has also undergone an episode of severe gastroenteritis 2 days ago. The serum lithium was found to be 1.95 meq/Lit. The probable cause for his present state is-

A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after her mother called an ambulance. The patient has a history of chronic schizophrenia, which is being treated with antipsychotics. The dosage was recently increased on these medications. In the emergency room the patient has a temperature of 39.44°C (103°F), is rigid, and has a blood pressure alternating between 120/65 and 100/45. Which of the following levels should be closely monitored?

A 56-year-old woman who was diagnosed with paranoid schizophreniain her early twenties has received daily doses of various typical neuroleptics for many years. For the past 2 years, she has had symptoms of tardive dyskinesia. Discontinuation of the neuroleptic is not possible because she becomes aggressive and violent in response to command hallucinations when she is not medicated. Which of the following actions should be taken next?
questions.correct_answer: E. Switch the patient to clozapine

questions.text: A middle aged man suddenly becomes detached, and starts writing poems and stories, although it couldn’t be understood by anyone because of language and context was also not rational. Most probable diagnosis?
A patient was on treatment with trifluperazine for some time. He presents with complaint of hyperthermia, lethargy and sweating. Needed investigations are

options.label: C
options.text: ECG, chest X ray and hemogram

options.label: D
options.text: Hemogram, CPK and Renal function test

questions.correct_answer: D. Hemogram, CPK and Renal function test

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman complains that she is gaining weight since she started taking chlorpromazine for chronic undifferentiated schizophrenia. A complete review of systems and history shows evidence of breast enlargement and lactation. However, a serum pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following antipsychotics would be a good choice for a treatment change?

A young boy earlier diagnosed as schizophrenia was taking some antipsychotic medication. He presented to casualty with sudden twisting of neck muscles, tremulousness of hands, stiffening of fingers, protrusion of tongue, he is frightened and restless. You are in the casualty, how will you manage the patient

options.label: D
options.text: Reassure the attendants that the patient has nothing serious and is just a dissociative symptoms

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a past history of recurrent psychotic depression is admitted to a locked ward during a relapse. On the day of admission, she is placed on nortriptyline 50 mg and risperidone 2 mg at bedtime. Ten days later, the patient reports with great concern that her nipples are leaking. Which class of medications is most commonly known to cause this condition?

22 years old Babu had fight with his neighbor’s son. Next day, which going to the bus stop, he felt that 2 uniformed policemen were following him. On reaching home he was frightened and he felt that the neighbours were using radio waves to control his mind. What is his symptom

A 58-year-old male presents to his primary care doctor with the complaint of vision changes over the last several months. The patient's past medical history is notable for schizophrenia which has been well-controlled for the last 25 years on chlorpromazine. Which of the following is likely to be seen on ophthalmoscopy?

A 24-year-old man is brought to your emergency department under arrest by the local police. The patient was found naked at a busy intersection jumping up and down on top of a car. Interviewing the patient, you discover that he has not slept in 2 days because he does not feel tired. He reports hearing voices. The patient was previously hospitalized 1 year ago with auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and a normal mood. What is the most likely diagnosis?
In a young male, history of firm unshakable belief of hands passing through the body& gripping his lungs indicates

A 28 year old female presents with complains of reduced sleep with disorganized behaviour since 9 months. She feels there is a camera fixed behind her head which always follows her. Which of the following is likely diagnosis –

A 23 year old engineering student is brought by his family to the hospital with history of gradual onset of suspiciousness, muttering and smiling without clear reason, decreased socialization, violent outbursts, and lack of interest in studies for 8 months. Mental status examination revealed a blunt affect, thought broadcast, a relatively preserved cognition, impaired judgment and insight. He is most likely to be suffering from
A patient of schizophrenia on neuroleptics, his psychotic symptoms get relieved but developed sadness, talks less to others, remain on bed, all of following are likely causes except -

options.label: D
options.text: He is reacting to external stimuli

questions.correct_answer: D. He is reacting to external stimuli

questions.text: A 30 year old unmarried woman from lower socioeconomic status family believes that a rich boy staying in her neighbourhood is in deep love withher. The boy clearly denies his love towards this lady. Still the lady insists that his denial is a secret affirmation of his love towards her. She makesdesperate attempts to meet the boy despite resistance from her family. She also develops sadness at times when her effort to meet the boy does not materialize. She is able to maintain her daily routine. She however, remains preoccupied with the thoughts this boy. She is likely to be suffering from

A 22-year-old male patient has been brought to OPD by his family members with history of loosening of clothes at inappropriate places. There are several times when he laughs inappropriately during the interview. His speech is confusing and unpredictably shifts from one topic to another. There is also history of mirror gazing and giggling to self. What is the most likely diagnosis:

A 30 year old man since 2 months suspects that his wife is having an affair with his boss. He thinks his friend is also involved from abroad and is providing technological support. He thinks people talk ill about him. His friends tried to convince him but he is not convinced at all. Otherwise he is normal, he doesn’t have any thought disorder or any other inappropriate behavior. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20 year old boy c/o hearing of voices, aggressive behavior since 2 days. He has fever since 2 days. When asked, his family said he has been muttering to self and gesticulating. There is no h/o of psychiatric illness. Likely diagnosis here is:

A 16 year old boy does not attend school because of the fear of being harmed by school mates. He thinks that his classmates laugh at and talk about him. He is even scared of going out to the market. He is most likely suffering from

A 22 y/o male with the diagnosis of schizophrenia was started on Risperidone 8 mg/d. Despite 6 weeks of continuous therapy patient did not show any improvement and his medications were changed to Haloperidol which was gradually increased to 20 mg/d. The patient did not show any response and continues to be symptomatic. What is the next best course of action

options.label: A
options.text: A combination of two typical antipsychotics

options.label: B
options.text: A combination of typical and atypical antipsychotics

questions.text: A 30 – years old pregnant woman comes to your clinic with decreased sleep, increased appetite and hyperactivity for 2 weeks. A diagnosis of mania is made. Further probing reveals four episodes of major depression in the past two years. What drug will you prescribe to the patients?

A patient with complaints of having a deformed nose. He has visited several plastic surgeons but they have assured that there is nothing wrong with his nose. In spite of these reassurances, he continues to believe that his nose is deformed, He also complains that nobody takes him seriously because of the deformity of his nose, and he is extremely embarrassed because of this. he is most probably suffering from

A patient with schizophrenia has had a poor response to several trials of typical antipsychotic medications, risperidone and olanzapine. His psychiatrist recommends a trial of clozapine. What factor can represent a relative contraindication to the use of this medication?

options.label: A
options.text: A history of severe extrapyramidal symptoms while on haloperidol

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of mild tardive dyskinesia

options.label: C
options.text: A history of recurrent depressive symptoms

questions.text: A young man with a diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia is hospitalized for the third time in the space of six months for acute exacerbations of his symptoms. He has been compliant with his antipsychotic medications and has kept his monthly doctor appointments. When his parents come to visit, they worry about the patient’s unkempt appearance and urge him to take better care of yourself. They show their disappointment when they learn that the patient has not participated in groups and has been spending most of his time in his room. Choose the most appropriate statement

options.label: A
options.text: Schizophrenic patients do not need constant encouragement to stay motivated

options.label: B
options.text: Family style of interaction makes no difference in the prognosis

options.label: C
options.text: Intrusive and critical families have a detrimental effect on schizophrenic patients

options.label: D
options.text: Family therapy has not proved to be of value in the treatment of schizophrenia

questions.correct_answer: C. Intrusive and critical families have a detrimental effect on schizophrenic patients

questions.text: A Patient of schizophrenia on chlorpromazine (CPZ) develops auditory hallucination again. The next drug to be given is:
What is produced by the supersensitivity of dopamine receptors?
PANSS scale is used in: (MH-PG)
The following person shown in the figure, can maintain this posture for a long period of time. What is the most effective first line treatment for this patient.
Which of the following is false concerning steroid induced psychosis:

options.label: A
options.text: Hallucination are usually visual in nature

options.label: B
options.text: It has been reported that postmenopausal women may be at greater risk.

options.label: C
options.text: Resolution usually occurs rapidly with discontinuation of reduction of the steroids.

options.label: D
options.text: A history of mood disorder appears to be a risk factor

questions.correct_answer: D. A history of mood disorder appears to be a risk factor

questions.text: Abnormalities in which of the following systems have not been reported in catatonia:
Which of the following is true of postpartum psychosis:

options.label: A
options.text: Early treatment can decrease episode length and it may last less than a week.

options.label: B
options.text: In general those who have the disorder a poor prognosis

options.label: C
options.text: Women with this illness may be at decreased risk of later psychiatric admission

questions.correct_answer: A. Early treatment can decrease episode length and it may last less than a week.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about late onset schizophrenia?

options.label: A
options.text: It occurs more frequently in older women

options.label: B
options.text: Those with this disorder tend to have fewer negative symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: It does not respond to the usual treatments

questions.correct_answer: D. It does not respond to the usual treatments

questions.text: Doppelganger is -
questions.correct_answer: B. Feeling of double of oneself

questions.text: Which of the following is not an environmental risk factor for schizophrenia?
Schizophrenia is a common presentation in which genetic disease?

A 45-years-old man with chronic psychotic disorder is interviewed after being admitted to a psychiatric unit. He mimics the examiner’s body posture and movements during the interview. Which of the following terms best characterizes this patient’s symptom?

A 55-year-old woman was diagnosed with schizophrenia at the age of 22. If this diagnosis was appropriate, the volume of the hippocampus, the size of the cerebral ventricles, and glucose utilization in the frontal cortex of this patient are now most likely to be, respectively
